article.title: In-medium properties of pseudoscalar $D_s$ and $B_s$ mesons

multiple_choice_question.text:
Figure 1 shows the variation of shift in mass of pseudoscalar D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons as a function of squared Borel mass parameter, M<sup>2</sup> for baryonic densities ρ<sub>0</sub> and 4ρ<sub>0</sub>.  Which of the following statements about the shift in mass is **FALSE**?

**(A)** The mass shift is negative for both D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons.
**(B)** The mass shift increases with increasing baryonic density.
**(C)** The mass shift is greater for B<sub>s</sub> mesons than for D<sub>s</sub> mesons.
**(D)** The mass shift is positive for D<sub>s</sub> mesons at temperature T = 100 MeV and strangeness fraction f<sub>s</sub> = 0.5.
choices: The mass shift is negative for both D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons.
The mass shift increases with increasing baryonic density.
The mass shift is greater for B<sub>s</sub> mesons than for D<sub>s</sub> mesons.
The mass shift is positive for D<sub>s</sub> mesons at temperature T = 100 MeV and strangeness fraction f<sub>s</sub> = 0.5.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows the variation of shift in decay constants of pseudoscalar D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons as a function of squared Borel mass parameter, M<sup>2</sup> for baryonic densities ρ<sub>0</sub> and 4ρ<sub>0</sub>. What happens to the decay constants of both D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons as the baryonic density increases?

Figure 3 compares the strange quark condensate and the mass of the D<sub>s</sub>(1968) meson as a function of baryonic density. What is the relationship between these two quantities as calculated using both the chiral SU(3) model and linear density approximation?
choices: As strange quark condensate increases, the mass of the D<sub>s</sub> meson also increases.
The strange quark condensate and the mass of the D<sub>s</sub> meson are not correlated.
Both the strange quark condensate and the mass of the D<sub>s</sub> meson decrease with increasing baryonic density.
The chiral SU(3) model predicts a significant increase in the mass of the D<sub>s</sub> meson, while linear density approximation predicts a slight decrease.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 illustrates the contribution of individual condensates to the shift in mass of D<sub>s</sub> and B<sub>s</sub> mesons in a symmetric hyperonic medium at T = 100 MeV and ρ<sub>B</sub> = 4ρ<sub>0</sub>. Which condensate has the most significant impact on the mass shift?
